abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings show an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, with only modest
            institutional development impacts. These unsuccessful
            ratings provide lessons in administering student loans, and
            in providing equitable financing for higher education.
            During project preparation, and appraisal, lessons suggest
            the involvement of all stakeholders (including the private
            sector), to uphold the public interest, and be subjected to
            market discipline, in order to ensure a transparent
            management, based on an analytical framework, and
            assessments of socioeconomic profiles of students, setting
            realistic targets. To this end, project design should ensure
            diversified instruments for financial assistance, less
            dependent on data, and the capacity of the implementing
            agency, but more cost-effective. Lessons on project
            implementation, supervision, and country dialogue, focus on
            the effective provision of technical assistance, and the use
            of more specific legal covenants linking the provision of
            data on loan repayment, defaults, and arrears to a continued
            disbursement, but which alerts the student loan bureau to
            monitor these indicators.

5082894.trustfund: TF034754-JAMAICA - STUDENT LOAN PROJECT,TF039096-JAMAICA - ESW ROSE AND STUDENT LOAN,TF022214-CANADIAN GENERAL CTF II-CARIBBEAN

abstracts.cdata!:
At its very broadest level, the Student
            Loan Project supports the government's objective of
            shifting public resources towards levels of education where
            the social returns are highest. Specifically, the project
            will: a) provide Jamaican students with adequate financing
            options to pay for their share of higher education on an
            ongoing basis; b) increase equitable access to tertiary
            education and improve targeting of subloans; and c) increase
            financial sustainability and administrative efficiency of
            the Students' Loan Bureau (SLB) through a consolidated
            student loan program. The project will support: a) the
            restructuring of the SLB to focus on loan approach, improved
            loan targeting and impact evaluation; b) the expansion of a
            targeted student loan program administered by the commercial
            banking system; c) the establishment of a grant-in-aid Fund
            for students least able to pay; and d) the development and
            implementation of a public awareness campaign to inform
            students and their families of policy changes with respect
            to cost recovery and financing options for tertiary
            education, including the Grant-in-Aid program.
